PartOfSpeech.Name: Adverb
PartOfSpeech.Description: An adverb, narrowly defined, is a part of speech whose members modify verbs for such categories as time, manner, place, or direction. An adverb, broadly defined, is a part of speech whose members modify any constituent class of words other than nouns, such as verbs, adjectives, adverbs, phrases, clauses, or sentences. Under this definition, the possible type of modification depends on the class of the constituent being modified.

PartOfSpeech.Name: Noun
PartOfSpeech.Description: A noun is a broad classification of parts of speech which include substantives and nominals.

PartOfSpeech.Name: Pro-form
PartOfSpeech.Description: A pro-form is a part of speech whose members usually substitute for other constituents, including phrases, clauses, or sentences, and whose meaning is recoverable from the linguistic or extralinguistic context.

PartOfSpeech.Name: Pronoun
PartOfSpeech.Description: A pronoun is a pro-form which functions like a noun and substitutes for a noun or noun phrase.

PartOfSpeech.Name: Verb
PartOfSpeech.Description: A verb is a part of speech whose members typically signal events and actions; constitute, singly or in a phrase, a minimal predicate in a clause; govern the number and types of other constituents which may occur in the clause; and, in inflectional languages, may be inflected for tense, aspect, voice, modality, or agreement with other constituents in person, number, or grammatical gender.

MoInflAffixTemplate.Name: Template to test irregularly inflected forms

PartOfSpeech.Name: Intransitive verb
PartOfSpeech.Description: An intransitive verb is a verb that cannot take a direct object, and describes a property, state, or situation involving only one participant.

PhPhoneme.Description: Orthographic hyphen used before reduplication suffix

MoEndoCompound.Name: left headed rule
MoEndoCompound.Description: My left-headed rule: result is a noun.

MoEndoCompound.Name: right-headed
MoEndoCompound.Description: My right-headed rule: result is still a pro form

MoMorphType.Name: discontiguous phrase
MoMorphType.Description: A discontiguous phrase has discontiguous constituents which (a) are separated from each other by one or more intervening constituents, and (b) are considered either (i) syntactically contiguous and unitary, or (ii) realizing the same, single meaning. An example is French ne...pas.

MoMorphType.Name: infixing interfix
MoMorphType.Description: An infixing interfix is an infix that can occur between two roots or stems.

MoMorphType.Name: suffixing interfix
MoMorphType.Description: A suffixing interfix is an suffix that can occur between two roots or stems.

MoMorphType.Name: particle
MoMorphType.Description: A particle is a word that does not belong to one of the main classes of words, is invariable in form, and typically has grammatical or pragmatic meaning.

MoMorphType.Name: phrase
MoMorphType.Description: A phrase is a syntactic structure that consists of more than one word but lacks the subject-predicate organization of a clause.

MoMorphType.Name: prefixing interfix
MoMorphType.Description: A prefixing interfix is a prefix that can occur between two roots or stems.

MoMorphType.Name: clitic
MoMorphType.Description: A clitic is a morpheme that has syntactic characteristics of a word, but shows evidence of being phonologically bound to another word. Orthographically, it stands alone.

MoMorphType.Name: infix
MoMorphType.Description: An infix is an affix that is inserted within a root or stem.

MoMorphType.Name: prefix
MoMorphType.Description: A prefix is an affix that is joined before a root or stem.

MoMorphType.Name: simulfix
MoMorphType.Description: A simulfix is a change or replacement of vowels or consonants (usually vowels) which changes the meaning of a word. (Note: the parser does not currently handle simulfixes.)

MoMorphType.Name: suffix
MoMorphType.Description: A suffix is an affix that is attached to the end of a root or stem.

MoMorphType.Name: suprafix
MoMorphType.Description: A suprafix is a kind of affix in which a suprasegmental is superimposed on one or more syllables of the root or stem, signalling a particular morphosyntactic operation. (Note: the parser does not currently handle suprafixes.)

MoMorphType.Name: circumfix
MoMorphType.Description: A circumfix is an affix made up of two separate parts which surround and attach to a root or stem.

MoMorphType.Name: enclitic
MoMorphType.Description: An enclitic is a clitic that is phonologically joined at the end of a preceding word to form a single unit. Orthographically, it may attach to the preceding word.

MoMorphType.Name: proclitic
MoMorphType.Description: A proclitic is a clitic that precedes the word to which it is phonologically joined. Orthographically, it may attach to the following word.

MoMorphType.Name: bound root
MoMorphType.Description: A bound root is a root which cannot occur as a separate word apart from any other morpheme.

MoMorphType.Name: root
MoMorphType.Description: A root is the portion of a word that (i) is common to a set of derived or inflected forms, if any, when all affixes are removed, (ii) is not further analyzable into meaningful elements, being morphologically simple, and, (iii) carries the principle portion of meaning of the words in which it functions.

MoMorphType.Name: bound stem
MoMorphType.Description: A bound stem is a stem which cannot occur as a separate word apart from any other morpheme.

MoMorphType.Name: stem
MoMorphType.Description: "A stem is the root or roots of a word, together with any derivational affixes, to which inflectional affixes are added." (LinguaLinks Library). A stem "may consist solely of a single root morpheme (i.e. a 'simple' stem as in man), or of two root morphemes (e.g. a 'compound' stem, as in blackbird), or of a root morpheme plus a derivational affix (i.e. a 'complex' stem, as in manly, unmanly, manliness). All have in common the notion that it is to the stem that inflectional affixes are attached." (Crystal, 1997:362)

LexEntryInflType.Name: Irregularly Inflected Form
LexEntryInflType.Description: An Irregularly Inflected Form is an inflected form of the lexeme that is different from what you would expect from the normal rules of the grammar.

LexEntryInflType.Name: Past
LexEntryInflType.Description: The past tense form of a verb that does not take the regular inflectional affix for past tense.

LexEntryInflType.Name: Plural
LexEntryInflType.Description: The plural form of a noun that does not take the regular inflectional affix for plural.

LexSense.Definition: This is the definition for ba and it means second person.

FsFeatStrucType.Name: Noun agreement
FsFeatStrucType.Description: Features common to agreement on nouns.

FsFeatStrucType.Name: Subject agreement
FsFeatStrucType.Description: Features common to subject agreement on verbs.

FsFeatStrucType.Name: Pronoun agreement
FsFeatStrucType.Description: Features common to agreement on pronouns.

FsClosedFeature.Name: number
FsClosedFeature.Description: Number is a grammatical category of nouns, pronouns, and verb agreement that expresses count distinctions (such as "one" or "more than one"). The count distinctions typically, but not always, correspond to the actual count of the referents of the marked noun or pronoun.

FsSymFeatVal.Name: singular number
FsSymFeatVal.Description: Singular number is number that refers to one member of a designated class.

FsSymFeatVal.Name: plural number
FsSymFeatVal.Description: Plural number is number that expresses reference to a quantity greater than that expressed by the largest specific number category in a language, such as "more than one" in English, and "more than two" in some other languages.

FsClosedFeature.Name: gender
FsClosedFeature.Description: Grammatical gender is a noun class system, composed of two or three classes, whose nouns that have human male and female referents tend to be in separate classes. Other nouns that are classified in the same way in the language may not be classed by any correlation with natural sex distinctions.

FsSymFeatVal.Name: feminine gender
FsSymFeatVal.Description: Feminine gender is a grammatical gender that (1) marks nouns that have human or animal female referents, and (2) often marks nouns that have referents that do not carry distinctions of sex.

FsSymFeatVal.Name: masculine gender
FsSymFeatVal.Description: Masculine gender is a grammatical gender that (1) marks nouns having human or animal male referents, and (2) often marks nouns having referents that do not have distinctions of sex.

FsComplexFeature.Name: noun agreement
FsComplexFeature.Description: This contains the set of features used in noun agreement.

FsComplexFeature.Name: subject agreement
FsComplexFeature.Description: This contains the set of features used in subject agreement.

FsClosedFeature.Name: aspect
FsClosedFeature.Description: Aspect is a grammatical category associated with verbs that expresses a temporal view of the event or state expressed by the verb.

FsSymFeatVal.Name: continuous aspect
FsSymFeatVal.Description: Continuous aspect is an imperfective aspect that expresses an ongoing, but not habitual, occurrence of the state or event expressed by the verb.

FsClosedFeature.Name: absolute tense
FsClosedFeature.Description: Absolute tense is a tense that refers to a time in relation to the moment of utterance.

FsSymFeatVal.Name: past tense
FsSymFeatVal.Description: Past tense is an absolute tense that refers to a time before the moment of utterance.

FsSymFeatVal.Name: future tense
FsSymFeatVal.Description: Future tense is an absolute tense that refers to a time after the moment of utterance.

FsSymFeatVal.Name: present tense
FsSymFeatVal.Description: Present tense is an absolute tense that refers to the moment of utterance. It often refers to events or states that do not merely coincide with the moment of utterance, such as those that are (1) continuous, (2) habitual, or (3) lawlike.

FsComplexFeature.Name: pronoun agreement
FsComplexFeature.Description: This contains the set of features used in pronoun agreement.

FsClosedFeature.Name: continuant
FsClosedFeature.Description: “Continuant features describe the passage of air through the vocal tract. [+cont] segments are produced without any significant obstruction in the tract, and so air passes through in a continuous stream. [-cont] segments on the other hand have such an obstruction, and so occlude the air flow at some point of articulation.”

FsClosedFeature.Name: lateral
FsClosedFeature.Description: “This feature designates the shape and positioning of the tongue with respect to the oral tract. [+lat] segments are produced as the center of the tongue rises to contact the roof of the mouth, thereby blocking air from flowing centrally through the oral tract and instead forcing more lateral flow along the lowered side(s) of the tongue.”

FsClosedFeature.Name: round
FsClosedFeature.Description: “[+round] are produced with lip rounding. [-round] are not.”

FsClosedFeature.Name: strident
FsClosedFeature.Description: “The strident feature applies to obstruents only and refers to a type of friction that is noisier that [sic] usual. This is caused by high energy white noise.”

FsClosedFeature.Name: pharyngeal
FsClosedFeature.Description: "Pharyngeals are formed by a constiction at the back wall of the pharynx with the root of the tongue.”

FsClosedFeature.Name: retracted tongue root
FsClosedFeature.Description: Possibly related to ATR and tense. “[+ATR] involves a forward position of the tongue body, with concomitant enlargement of the pharynx, while [+RTR] involves a retraction and lowering of the tongue body, with concomitant narrowing of the pharynx.”

FsClosedFeature.Name: long
FsClosedFeature.Description: “This feature applies to long vs. short segments and is often in competition with [+/-tense].”

FsClosedFeature.Name: nasal
FsClosedFeature.Description: “This feature describes the position of the velum. [+nas] segments are produced by lowering the velum so that air can pass through the nasal tract. [-nas] segments conversely are produced with a raised velum, blocking the passages of air to the nasal tract and shunting it to the oral tract.”

FsClosedFeature.Name: approximant
FsClosedFeature.Description: A “[f]rictionless continuant. [A] consonantal sound articulated in a manner involving an opening in the oral tract not radical enough to produce audible friction.”

FsClosedFeature.Name: syllabic
FsClosedFeature.Description: “Syllabic segments may function as the nucleus of a syllable, while their counterparts, the [-syl] segments, may not.”

FsClosedFeature.Name: sonorant
FsClosedFeature.Description: “This feature describes the type of oral constriction that can occur in the vocal tract. [+son] designates the vowels and sonorant consonants, which are produced without the imbalance of air pressure in the vocal tract that might cause turbulence. [-son] alternatively describes the obstruents, articulated with a noticeable turbulence caused by an imbalance of air pressure in the vocal tract.”

FsClosedFeature.Name: tense
FsClosedFeature.Description: “This feature (mainly) applies to the position of the root of the tongue when articulating vowels. [+tense] vowels have an advanced tongue root. In fact, this feature is often referred to as Advanced tongue root, though there is a debate on whether tense and ATR are same or different features.”

FsClosedFeature.Name: delayed release
FsClosedFeature.Description: “This feature distinguishes stops from affricates. Affricates are designated [+dr].”

FsClosedFeature.Name: implosive
FsClosedFeature.Description: “Stop consonant formed with a glottalic ingressive airstream, tat is, with inflowing release of air using suction developed by downward movement of the larynx while another complete obstruction is maintained further forward in the oral tract.”

FsClosedFeature.Name: low
FsClosedFeature.Description: “[+low] segments bunch the dorsum to a position low in the mouth.”

FsClosedFeature.Name: anterior
FsClosedFeature.Description: “Anterior segments are articulated with the tip or blade of the tongue at or in front of the alveolar ridge.”

FsClosedFeature.Name: back
FsClosedFeature.Description: “[+back] segments are produced with the tongue dorsum bunched and retracted slightly to the back of the mouth. [-back] segments are bunched and extended slightly forward.”

FsClosedFeature.Name: front
FsClosedFeature.Description: “(Of vowels) Articulated with the highest point of the tongue in the front region of the mouth, i.e. below the hard palate.”

FsClosedFeature.Name: dorsal
FsClosedFeature.Description: “Dorsal sounds are articulated by raising the dorsum of the tongue. All vowels are DORSAL sounds.”

FsClosedFeature.Name: consonantal
FsClosedFeature.Description: “Consonantal segments are produced with an audible constriction in the vocal tract, like plosives, affricates, fricatives, nasals, laterals and [r]. Vowels, glides and laryngeal segments are not consonantal.”

FsClosedFeature.Name: advanced tongue root
FsClosedFeature.Description: “This feature (mainly) applies to the position of the root of the tongue when articulating vowels.” See also tense.

FsClosedFeature.Name: distributed
FsClosedFeature.Description: “For [+dist] segments the tongue is extended for some distance in the mouth.”

FsClosedFeature.Name: labial
FsClosedFeature.Description: “Labial segments are articulated with the lips.”

FsClosedFeature.Name: voice
FsClosedFeature.Description: “This feature indicates whether vibration of the vocal folds occurs with the articulation of the segment.”

FsClosedFeature.Name: coronal
FsClosedFeature.Description: “Coronal sounds are articulated with the tip and/or blade of the tongue.”

FsClosedFeature.Name: spread glottis
FsClosedFeature.Description: “Used to indicate the aspiration of a segment, this feature denotes the openness of the glottis. For [+sg] the vocal folds are spread apart wide enough for frication to occur; for [-sg] there is not the same friction-inducing spreading.”

FsClosedFeature.Name: labio-dental
FsClosedFeature.Description: “Articulated by bringing the lower lip into contact with the upper teeth.”

FsClosedFeature.Name: constricted glottis
FsClosedFeature.Description: “The constricted glottis features denotes the degree of closure of the glottis. [+cg] implies that the vocal folds are held closely together, enough so that air cannot pass through momentarily. [-cg] implies the opposite.”

FsClosedFeature.Name: high
FsClosedFeature.Description: “[+high] segments raise the dorsum close to the palate. [-high] segments do not.”
